The brahman thought to himself:

This person is unfilial, there is no comparison!
The brahman entered the city, went to the farmer's house, saw the dead child's mother, and immediately said:
Your son has already died. His father sent a message, just to bring food for one person.
Why do you not think of your son?
The child's mother then told a parable to the brahman, saying:
When the child came to be conceived, I did not call him. Now that the child is leaving, I cannot keep him.
It's like a traveler passing through a host's house. Now the guest is leaving on his own. How can he stay?

My mother and child are also like this. Coming and going, advancing and stopping, are not within my power. Following their past actions, I cannot keep them. What benefit is there in grieving and crying for the dead?
He also said to his sister:
Your younger brother has already died. Why don't you cry?
The sister told the brahman a parable, saying:

My brothers are like a skilled craftsman who enters the mountains to cut wood, binds them into a large raft, places it in the water, and suddenly encounters a great wind that blows the raft apart. Following the water, they flow away, scattered before and after, not looking out for each other;

My younger brother is also like this. Causes and conditions come together, born in the same family, following the length of life, birth and death are impermanent, and what comes together will separate.
My younger brother's life is over. Following his past actions, I cannot keep him. What benefit is there in grieving and crying for the dead?
He then said to his wife:
Your husband has already died, why don't you cry?
The wife told the brahman a parable, saying:

My husband and I are like flying birds. In the evening we roost in a tall tree, staying together overnight. In the morning we each fly away to seek food. When there is a reason we meet, when there is no reason we part.

My husband and I are also like this. Coming and going, advancing and stopping, are not within my power. Following his past actions, I cannot keep him. What benefit is there in grieving and crying for the dead?

When the brahmin heard this, his mind was confused and his eyes were darkened, not knowing east from west:
I heard that in this country, people are filial, serve, respect, and honor the Three Jewels, so I came from afar wanting to study;
Having arrived here, I have gained nothing.

Great crying and little crying, what benefit is there to the dead?

In the world, worldly people, for countless eons, have been transmigrating in birth and death, their spirits do not perish, they die and are reborn, like a turning wheel, without rest, turning away from death and toward life, not reached by worry and sorrow.
When the brahman heard this, his mind opened up and his thoughts were resolved, he no longer had any worries or distress:
I have heard the Buddha's teachings, like a sick person being cured, like the blind gaining sight, like darkness encountering light.
Then the brahman attained the path of a stream-enterer.

All deaths are not enough to cry over, if you want to do for the deceased, invite the Buddha and Sangha, burn incense and make offerings, recite the scriptures, be able to make prostrations every day, and make offerings to the Three Jewels with utmost sincerity, this is the most important.
Then the brahman bowed his head in reverence, received the teachings, and left.
